references.A94DUN01NAUS: Dunk, J. R., and R. J. Cooper. 1994. Territory-size regulation in black-shouldered kites. Auk 111:588-595.
references.B90SIB02NAUS: Sibley, C.G., and B.L. Monroe. 1990. Distribution and taxonomy of birds of the world. Yale University Press, New Haven, Connecticut. xxiv + 1111 pp.
references.A88GAT01NAUS: Gatz, T. A., et al. 1988. Black-shouldered kite. Pages 48-53 in Glinski et al., eds. Proc. Southwest Raptor Manage. Symp. and Workshop. National Wildlife Federation Sci. and Tech. Ser. No. 11.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B88PAL01NAUS: Palmer, R. S., editor. 1988. Handbook of North American birds. Vol. 4. [Diurnal raptors, part 1]. Yale University Press, New Haven. vii + 433 pp.
references.B87PEN01NAUS: Pendleton, B. A. Giron, et al. 1987. Raptor management techniques manual. National Wildlife Federation, Sci. and Tech. Ser. No. 10. 420 pp.
references.A92CLA01NAUS: Clark, W. S., and R. C. Banks. 1992. The taxonomic status of the white-tailed kite. Wilson Bull. 104:571-579.
references.W95DUN01USGP: Dunk, Jeffrey R. 1995. White-tailed Kite (Elanus leucurus), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/178.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.B88ROO01NAUS: Root, T. 1988. Atlas of wintering North American birds:An analysis of Christmas Bird Count data. University of Chicago Press. 336 pp.
references.B89RID01NAUS: Ridgely, R. S., and J. A. Gwynne, Jr. 1989. A guide to the birds of Panama with Costa Rica, Nicaragua, and Honduras. Second edition. Princeton Univ. Press, Princeton, New Jersey. 534 pp.
references.A80PRU01NAUS: Pruett-Jones, S. G., M. Pruett-Jones, and R. L. Knight. 1980. The white-tailed kite in North and Middle America:current status and recent population changes. Am. Birds 34:682-688.
references.A89CUR01NAUS: Curnutt, J. L. 1989. Nesting of the black-shouldered kite (ELANUS CAERULEUS) in Everglades National Park. Florida Field Nat. 17:77-79.
references.B89STI01NAUS: Stiles, F.G., and A.F. Skutch. 1989. A guide to the birds of Costa Rica. Comstock Publ. Associates, Cornell University Press, Ithaca, New York. 511 pp.
references.B90JOH01NAUS: Johnsgard, P.A. 1990. Hawks, eagles, and falcons of North America. Smithsonian Inst. Press, Washington, D.C. xvi + 403 pp.
references.A58PAR01NAUS: Parkes, K. C. 1958. Specific relationships in the genus ELANUS. Condor 60:139-140.

habitat_description:
The White-tailed Kite’s (Elanus leucurus) range has been expanding in recent decades.  Gatz et al. (1985) hypothesized the reason for BSKI’s range expansion into the southwestern U.S. may be related to (1) the increase in suitable foraging habitat created by irrigated agricultural lands, (2) retired cropland and (3) grassland succession created by brush and tree removal operations.  SWGAP included the following narrative of the White-tailed Kite’s range in their habitat notes:
“As of 1984, there have been over 60 sightings (n ˜ 105) from 42 different localities in eight Arizona counties (Cochise, Graham, Maricopa, Pima, Pinal, Santa Cruz, Yavapai and Yuma; Gatz et al. 1985).  This species is considered a rare resident (Edison et al. 1995).  Upon publication of Monson and Phillips (1981), there were three substantiated reports, where this species was photographed, in Arizona (Monson and Phillips 1981).  It has been photographed within Altar Valley northeast of Baboquivari Peak, north of the Santa Rita Mountains and one near Hereford, Cochise County (Monson and Phillips 1981). Other reports include the west side of the Dragoon Mountains, Blue Point east of Phoenix, Kansas Settlement (Cochise County), near Sierra Vista, within the Cibola NWR, southeast of San Simon (Cochise County) and near Poston (Yuma County; Monson and Phillips 1981).  A breeding pair was confirmed in oak savanna approximately 150 meters from a residence near Sonoita, Santa Cruz County (Gatz et al. 1985).  Additional sightings reported were of single birds along the Colorado River, Yuma County (n = 3; Gatz et al. 1985), where Rosenberg et al. (1991) considered it a “rare visitor” to the Lower Colorado River valley.  Also, it has been observed in the Colorado River Delta, Mexico (Rosenberg et al. 1991).  Edison et al. (1995) suggest this species may be observed in Avra Valley (Pinal Air Park), Buenos Aires NWR and Hereford.  It is also believed to occur along and south of the Gila River (Johnson 1987).  Also, two pair were observed in the Santa Cruz wash channel on abandoned farmland 11 km south of Casa Grande, Pinal County (Gatz et al. 1985).  In New Mexico, this species is considered “occasional” in the southern portion of the state and “casual” at Las Vegas (Hubbard 1978).  In Utah, the first record of this species was in 1986 (Kingery 1987).  No additional records of this species in Utah were discovered.”

White-tailed Kites inhabit low elevation grasslands (grazed or ungrazed), agricultural areas, wetlands, oak-woodlands, and savannas (Dunk 1995).  This species typically nests in riparian trees adjacent to agricultural lands (Johnson 1987).  Two pair observed nesting in a row in cottonwood (Populus fremontii) trees (Gatz et al. 1985).  Also, it was observed nesting within an Emory oak (Quercus emoryi); nest height was ~10 meters (Gatz et al. 1985).  In the Lower Colorado River Valley, Arizona, this species typically hunts over agricultural lands and brushy vegetation bordering fields (Rosenberg et al. 1991).  In New Mexico, vegetation type was described as “low elevation wooded areas” (Hubbard 1978).  This may be as a nesting requirement only; however, this was not specified by the author. 

This species hunts in “open areas” including grasslands and agricultural fields (Johnson 1987).  Populations of this species may be correlated with rodent density (Dunk and Cooper 1994).

In Arizona, observations of this species range between 1000 to 3500 feet (300 – 1060 meters; Johnson 1987).  In New Mexico, this species occurs mainly at “lower elevations” (Hubbard 1978).  This species occurs primarily in southern Arizona with casual occurrences in New Mexico and one record in Utah.  The elevational range is estimated between 300 and 1060 meters.  N. Tarr, 9July20012.  Adapted from SWreGAP habitat notes.
